title: Leader of Hong Kong pro-democracy protests attacked with hammers
text:
Warning: Graphic Images

Jimmy Sham was rushed to hospital and is thought to be in a stable condition (Picture: AP/Avalon.red)

One of the leading figures of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy protests was left bleeding on the floor after being set upon by hammer and spanner wielding assailants.

Jimmy Sham of the Civil Human Rights Front was on his way to an evening meeting in Kowloon when four or five smashed him in the head.

The attack this evening was the second against Sham in under two months and came four days before a planned mass rally.

He was found by officers covered in blood before being rushed to hospital where he is in a stable condition.

The suspects escaped in a car which police were reportedly chasing after.

It was the second time he has been attacked in under two months (Picture: Avalon.red)

Bloodstains were left on the road after a gang of four or five men attacked (Picture: Reuters)

Pro-democracy lawmaker Lam Cheuk-ting protests shortly before Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam leaves the chamber (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Mr Sham has played a crucial role in Hong Kong’s biggest pro-democracy protests (Picture: AP)

Activists fear the attack was part of ‘a spreading political terror’ after four months of civil unrest in the semi-autonomous Chinese region.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Protesters fear the communist Beijing government is slowly chipping away at the territory’s democratic freedoms, triggering violent clashes in the streets with riot police.

According to witnesses, onlookers had a knife pointed at them when they tried to intervene in the attack on Mr Sham.

He was on his way to the group’s general meeting in Kowloon to discuss Sunday’s planned march when he was ambushed, reports South China Morning Post.

The group said the onslaught would have a ‘chilling effect’ on democracy campaigners but this week’s rally is still set to go ahead regardless.

Hours before the attack, Hong Kong’s leader Carrie Lam abandoned her annual address over heckles from pro-democracy lawmakers.

Police found him bleeding from his head and arms (Picture: AP)

Activists fear the attack was politically motivated (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

It comes as Lam’s leadership is undermined with a lack of trust from lawmakers (Picture: AP)

Campaigners fear the attack will have a ‘chilling effect’ on pro-democracy activists (Picture: AP)

They called her ‘the mother of the mafia police’ and forced her to walk out of the legislative council.

The hostile reception marked another slap in the face for the embattled chief executive as she grapples with violent demonstrations which have wrecked trust in the police and her leadership.

As she started to speak, chanting lawmakers held placards suggesting Lam has blood on her hands.

They also used a projector to light up Lam’s face and the wall behind her with the protest movement’s key demands.

Advertisement

Advertisement

One lawmaker wearing a paper mask with the face of Chinese President Xi Jinping tossed a placard as Lam walked out.

After two thwarted attempts, she resorted to delivering the speech 75 minutes late by video link, standing between the flags of Hong Kong and the People’s Republic of China.

The suspects reportedly fled in a car which officers were pursuing (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Lawmakers accuse Lam of having blood on her hands (Picture: Reuters)

It comes after four months of violent clashes with police over fears of China taking away Hong Kong’s freedoms (Picture: Reuters)

Lam said the territory was going through a ‘major crisis’ and appealed for its 7.5 million citizens to ‘cherish the city’.

She warned ‘continued violence and spread of hatred will erode the core values of Hong Kong.’

Later in a news conference, she made clear she would not resign and insisted there had been no erosion ‘whatsoever’ of Hong Kong’s freedoms.

The most recent protests were triggered in June by a now-withdrawn extradition bill which would allow some criminal suspects to be sent for trial in mainland China.

Demonstrators have since widened their demands to include direct elections for the city’s leaders and greater police accountability.

description: Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Jimmy Sham was attacked with hammers hours after Carrie Lam was heckled out of the legislative chamber.
